Build ID: 20110902180055

Steps to reproduce:

Compose a HTML mail


Actual results:

The HTML generated is formatted "to look pretty".
(e.g. indentation corresponding to tag level)
This has no use as nobody is supposed to look at the HTML anyway, when not debugging.
It only wastes space.
However, it sometimes causes undesired side-effects too.


Expected results:

There should be a pref to disable this "feature" and make it work as it always did.

comments.raw_text:
Please if there already is a hidden pref that can change this behavior, can someone
point me to it?
This is really a problem.
When people in our company discuss something in mail, it is customary to just add to
the existing mail keeping all previous discussion as quoted text.
After only a few replies, the quoted mail is indented all the way to the right margin
with only a single word of text on each line and some 60 spaces.
This wastes a lot of space and bandwidth, and causes trouble for some simplistic HTML
to text conversion that only strips the HTML tags and leaves the lines as is.
(which worked fine with mail produced by older versions of Seamonkey and Thunderbird)

I really need some way to turn off this unneccessary formatting of HTML text in mail.

comments.raw_text: I confirm this bug -- ah, feature -- in SeaMonkey 2.20.  I just replied to an email, typing about 200 bytes of text and the size of the email went from 38.5 kB (original) to 82.2 kB (sent reply), more than double what I received.  This is a colossal waste of storage space and bandwidth.  We need a switch in the about:config screen to turn automatic indenting of HTML off.  Indenting is useful for debugging, but the rest of the time it is not desired.

comments.raw_text:
Please consider disabling pretty print / indentation in Thunderbird, so that it would be possible to send newsletter emails like the one attached here without any unnecessary whitespace. 

See attached files: 
- A newsletter with HTML code indentation
  --> A German newspaper newsletter with the usual nested table layout, received and saved to disk as HTML with Thunderbird 52.5.2
  --> This very indentation is what you see when you use Thunderbird's "View Source" feature showing a window with the source code of the email.
- A newsletter without HTML code indentation
  --> The same saved newsletter. All whitespace not needed for the presented text has been removed.

Once rendered in a browser both files are of the same content, but the indented variant needs about 25% more disk space. 

Please let me know if you need any further material or detailed steps to reproduce.
